item.title: Live Updates: Israel Launches Invasion Into Southern Lebanon
item.description: Israeli troops crossed the border for the first time since 2006 in a ground operation targeting Hezbollah. The Israeli military called for evacuations of more than two dozen villages in southern Lebanon.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times

item.title: As Crisis Builds, Lebanon’s Government Is Nowhere to Be Found
item.description: Already crippled by years of economic decline, political paralysis and other crises, Lebanon has little but its own citizens’ grit to survive the Israel-Hezbollah conflict.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The aftermath of an Israeli strike in Hilaniyeh, Lebanon, last week, part of a bombing campaign that some experts have called one of the most intense in contemporary warfare.

item.title: Assange, in First Speech Since Release, Says He Was Jailed for Journalism
item.description: Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder, said in public remarks in Strasbourg, France, that his imprisonment had set a dangerous precedent.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Pascal Bastien/Associated Press
item.media:description: Julian Assange with his wife, Stella Assange, were in Strasbourg, France, on Tuesday.

item.title: Mexico’s First Female President Takes Office
item.description: A climate scientist and former mayor, Claudia Sheinbaum will be inaugurated on Tuesday as the first woman to lead the country.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:credit: Meghan Dhaliwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Claudia Sheinbaum will be Mexico’s first female president.

item.title: A New Fine-Dining Restaurant in London, Staffed by Ex-Homeless People
item.description: In London’s upmarket Primrose Hill, a Michelin-starred chef is employing people on the edge of homelessness as chefs, wait staff and cocktail makers.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The evening service. Mr. Simmonds revised the menu before opening to ensure dishes could be successfully executed by inexperienced workers.

item.title: Cambodia Arrests Mech Dara, Journalist Who Exposed Scam Centers
item.description: The charge of incitement came after the United States punished a tycoon for what it said was his role in the scam compounds.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Sun Narin
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Jack Brook, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Mech Dara, who has exposed human trafficking in online scam centers, in Siem Reap, Cambodia, in 2021.

item.title: Crisis at The Jewish Chronicle: Fabrications and Resignations
item.description: When several journalists resigned this month from the British newspaper over false news articles, they also raised a broader question about its ownership.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Jewish Chronicle, a weekly founded in 1841, bills itself as the world’s oldest Jewish newspaper.

item.title: Separated by the Ukraine War, Two Soul Mates Reconnect
item.description: Sofia Malina and Polina Muzhychkova met in the Ukrainian city of Mariupol, but were separated after it came under brutal assault by Russian forces. They were reunited after a long and harrowing saga.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Polina Muzhychkova, left, and Sofia Malina in Odesa, Ukraine, in July.

item.title: Zelensky Returns to Russian Strikes in Eastern Ukraine and Counterattacks in Kursk Region
item.description: Cities across Ukraine have suffered airstrikes in recent days, and Moscow is pressing a slow advance in the east. Kyiv has hit back against arms depots, trying to disrupt Russian logistics.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damage in Kurakhove, in eastern Ukraine. Moscow’s troops have been trying to encircle the town.

item.title: Dozens Feared Dead After Migrant Boat Sinks Off Canary Islands
item.description: At least nine people are known to have died in a sinking off the Canary Islands and 48 more are missing, the latest disaster on the perilous Atlantic crossing from West Africa.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Borja Suarez/Reuters
item.media:description: Rescuers helping some of the 27 people rescued at the port of La Restinga on the island of El Hierro, Spain, on Monday.

item.title: Marine Le Pen’s Party Goes on Trial in France on Embezzlement Charges
item.description: The defendants, including 26 other people, are charged with using European Parliament funds for unrelated party expenses.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: The French far-right leader Marine Le Pen speaking to journalists during the French parliamentary elections in Paris in July.

item.title: As Israel Strikes Hezbollah, Iran-Backed Militias Fail to Provide Aid
item.description: Iran united militias to take on Israel, but as the Israelis pummel one, Hezbollah, the rest have so far largely failed to come to its aid.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Alissa J. Rubin
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: After the killing of the Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah, Tehran has put his image on billboards. But it has not retaliated directly.

item.title: As Mexico’s President Steps Down, Some Laud His Legacy, but Others Fear It
item.description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador lifted millions out of poverty while eroding democratic norms, allowing his nationalist political movement to expand its sway.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero, Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Paulina Villegas
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Cesar Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico and his wife, Beatriz Gutiérrez Müller, during Independence Day celebrations in Mexico City this month.

item.title: How Mexican Novelist Yuri Herrera Found Himself in New Orleans
item.description: Much of Yuri Herrera’s work has focused on Mexican social realities. In “Season of the Swamp” he turns his attention to the uniquely American city that has been his home for 13 years.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin P. Russell
item.category: Signs Preceding the End of the World (Book)
item.media:credit: Annie Flanagan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Much of Yuri Herrera’s work has touched on social realities in Mexico. Now he has turned his attention to New Orleans, a uniquely American city that has been his home for 13 years.

item.title: In a Shattered Ukrainian Town, a Long Battle Nears a Sudden End
item.description: The loss of Vuhledar, at the intersection of two fronts, would complicate the defense of a regional transit hub and strengthen Russian supply lines, Ukrainian soldiers say.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the White Angels evacuation team, a special unit of Ukraine’s National Police, carrying a woman who has suffered a stroke, in the village of Zoriane, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Why Did Israel Send Troops Into Southern Lebanon?
item.description: Israel says it aims to cripple Hezbollah’s forces in an area of southern Lebanon that the armed group controls, and where it has built tunnels into Israel.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A U.N. peacekeeper in the southern Lebanese village of Yarine in July.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Israel Sends Troops Into Lebanon
item.description: Plus, creating fashion in prison.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:credit: Atef Safadi/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Israeli artillery shells hit in southern Lebanon yesterday.

item.title: Super Typhoon Krathon Nears Taiwan After Lashing the Philippines
item.description: The storm is expected to bring torrential rain this week to Taiwan’s south, including Kaohsiung, the island’s third-largest city.
item.dc:creator: John Liu and Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Humberto Ortega, Former Military Chief in Nicaragua, Dies at 77
item.description: Mr. Ortega, the estranged brother of President Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua, had been under house arrest for months after making statements that infuriated his sibling.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Miguel Alvarez/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Humberto Ortega, the former head of Nicaragua’s armed forces, during a news conference in Managua in 2000. His death was announced Monday.

item.title: Israel Sends Troops Into Southern Lebanon
item.description: Israel’s military said its forces had begun crossing over the Lebanon border to target Hezbollah infrastructure in villages close to the Israel-Lebanon border.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Baz Ratner/Associated Press
item.media:description: An Israeli mobile artillery unit firing a shell from northern Israel toward Lebanon from a position near the border on Monday.

item.title: Israeli Military Begins Ground Invasion of Southern Lebanon
item.description: The military said it was targeting Hezbollah infrastructure in villages close to the Israel-Lebanon border.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Julian E. Barnes, Ronen Bergman and Natan Odenheimer
item.category: Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents in central Beirut, Lebanon, cleaning up on Monday after an overnight bombing by Israeli forces. It was believed to have been the first Israeli strike in central Beirut since at least 2006.

item.title: Pentagon Sends Additional Troops to the Middle East
item.description: The additional forces, which one official placed at between 2,000 and 3,000, will bolster security for the 40,000 U.S. troops already in the region and help defend Israel, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Safin Hamid/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A convoy of U.S. military vehicles driving in Erbil, in northern Iraq, this month. The 40,000 American troops already in the Middle East are stationed on bases in Iraq and Syria, among other countries.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Israel Conducts Raids in Lebanon
item.description: Plus, creating fashion in prison.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli tank in a staging area in northern Israel on Sunday.

item.title: What to Know About the Axis of Resistance, the Iran-backed Militia Network
item.description: The alliance is under scrutiny after the recent Israeli strikes in Lebanon.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin, Ben Hubbard and Lazaro Gamio

item.title: Why Helene Was So Destructive in Florida, the Carolinas and Appalachia
item.description: Hurricanes typically weaken over land. But if the ground is already wet from earlier rains, storms can receive an extra jolt that keeps them churning.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Christian Monterrosa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damage to Highway 64 near Bat Cave, N.C., on Monday.

item.title: Russia to Boost Defense Budget as Ukraine War Drags On
item.description: The Kremlin plans a 25 percent increase to more than $145 billion in 2025, a year in which it had intended to cut military spending.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Preparing for a military parade in Moscow last year. The Kremlin plans to boost military spending by 25 percent in 2025.

item.title: U.S. and Allies Sound Alarm Over Their Adversaries’ Military Ties
item.description: The Biden administration is struggling to halt cooperation among Russia, China, North Korea and Iran. It feels urgency over the wars in Ukraine and the Middle East while also aiming to protect Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: In speeches and closed-door talks, most recently at the United Nations General Assembly in New York, U.S. officials have been sounding the alarm on the coalition of powers working to strengthen one another’s militaries to defeat America’s partners.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Pledges to Send Financial Aid to Palestine
item.description: An expected cash infusion for the Palestinian Authority would signal renewed Saudi backing for Palestinian statehood and help mend ties between Riyadh and the body that administers the West Bank.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians lining up this summer at A.T.M.s in Ramallah, in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.

item.title: Britain Shuts Down Last Coal Plant, ‘Turning Its Back on Coal Forever’
item.description: The Ratcliffe-on-Soar plant was the last surviving coal-burning power station in a country that birthed the Industrial Revolution and fed it with coal.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:credit: Rui Vieira/Associated Press
item.media:description: The 2,000-megawatt Ratcliffe-on-Soar power plant in England will close Monday.

item.title: U.S. Officials Believe Israel Will Not Conduct Full Invasion of Lebanon
item.description: After a weekend of intense talks, the American officials said they believed that Israel was planning only smaller, targeted incursions in southern Lebanon.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli military vehicle in northern Israel on Tuesday. Israeli special operations forces have been conducting raids into southern Lebanon.

item.title: Around the World, Diplomats Gird for a Trump Assault on Climate Action
item.description: Some leaders insist that the global clean energy transition will happen with or without the United States.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump addressing the 74th Session of the U.N. General Assembly in 2019.

item.title: Israel’s Attack in Central Beirut Was Its First There in Years
item.description: Here’s a look at where the Israeli military has been striking in the Beirut area recently.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Leatherby
item.media:credit: By The New York Times

item.title: Israeli Strike Inside Beirut City Limits Puts Residents on Edge
item.description: A blast in the Cola neighborhood was the first known Israeli strike in the central part of the city since a war with Hezbollah in 2006.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Hwaida Saad
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: An apartment block damaged by a blast on Monday in Beirut, Lebanon.

item.title: Hezbollah Deputy Commander Says Group Is Ready For Possible Ground Incursion
item.description: The televised statement by the deputy leader, Sheikh Naim Qassem, was the first public address by a senior Hezbollah figure since Israel’s killing of the group’s longtime chief, Hassan Nasrallah.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Al Manar TV, via Reuters
item.media:description: Hezbollah’s deputy leader, Sheikh Naim Qassem, speaks on video from an unknown location, days after the Hezbollah chief Hassan Nasrallah was killed in an Israeli airstrike.

item.title: Israeli Commandos Making Raids Into Lebanon, Officials Say
item.description: Brief incursions in recent days were to prepare the ground for a possible wider ground invasion, the officials said.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Ronen Bergman and Natan Odenheimer
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli tank in a staging area in northern Israel, on Sunday.

item.title: Senior Officer Gets 3 Years Over South Korea Crowd Crush
item.description: Lee Im-jae, a former district chief, is the most senior official to be convicted in connection with the 2022 disaster that killed nearly 160 Halloween partygoers.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Yonhap/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Lee Im-jae was the chief of police in Yongsan District, the area in central Seoul where the disaster happened.

item.title: Dockworkers Strike at U.S. Ports Could Begin Tuesday
item.description: A work stoppage at East and Gulf Coast ports would halt most activity at some of the busiest American ports.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis
item.category: Port of New York and New Jersey
item.media:credit: Kristen Zeis for The New York Times
item.media:description: The longshoremen’s union has not held a strike at all the East and Gulf Coast ports since 1977.

item.title: Here are the latest developments.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Julian E. Barnes, Ronen Bergman and Natan Odenheimer

item.title: Monday Briefing: The Aftermath of Nasrallah’s Death
item.description: Plus, we retraced one of Mayor Eric Adams’s lavish trips to Istanbul.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters attending the funeral of Hezbollah fighters in the southern suburbs of Beirut last week.

item.title: A Blast in Central Beirut Damages a Building
item.description: If the explosion is confirmed to be an Israeli attack, it would be the first Israeli strike within the Lebanese capital since the 2006 war with Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.category: Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine
item.media:credit: Fadel Itani/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Israel Targets Hezbollah in Lebanon, the Houthis in Yemen and Hamas in Gaza
item.description: The escalation of violence between Israel and Iran-backed proxies across the Middle East threatened to bring the combatants closer to an all-out regional war.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Maag, Euan Ward and Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli military forces in northern Israel, near Kiryat Shmona, on Sunday.

item.title: Austria’s Far Right Wins Election but May Fall Short of Forming a Government
item.description: The Freedom Party got nearly 30 percent of the national vote, but mainstream parties have vowed to join in a coalition government without the party’s pugilistic leader, Herbert Kickl.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Filip Singer/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Herbert Kickl, center left, leader of the Freedom Party of Austria, on Sunday in Vienna, where he said he has a clear mandate to form a government.

item.title: Monday Briefing: The Aftermath of Nasrallah’s Death
item.description: Plus, we retraced one of Mayor Eric Adams’s lavish trips to Istanbul.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters attending the funeral of Hezbollah fighters in the southern suburbs of Beirut last week.

item.title: Gideon Saar Joins Netanyahu Coalition
item.description: The addition of Gideon Saar to Benjamin Netanyahu’s coalition strengthens the prime minister’s political position.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Jalaa Marey/Pool, via Reuters
item.media:description: Gideon Saar had been a longtime opponent of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

item.title: Israel Strikes the Houthis, an Iranian Ally, in Yemen
item.description: The strike on power stations and a seaport, which killed four people, was the second known time that Israel has retaliated against the militant group’s attacks by striking in Yemen.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Abdallah Adel/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The capital of Yemen last week. The war between Israel and Hamas in Gaza has expanded to other parts of the Arab world where Iranian-backed groups dominate, including Yemen.

item.title: Nepal Flooding and Landslides Kill at Least 190 People
item.description: The mountainous country is experiencing more extreme weather driven by climate change, including melting glaciers that add to the frequency and severity of flooding.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma and Anupreeta Das
item.media:credit: Navesh Chitrakar/Reuters
item.media:description: Rescue workers retrieving bodies of victims on Sunday after a landslide in Dhading, Nepal.

item.title: Netanyahu, Ignoring Allies and Defying Critics, Basks in a Rare Triumph
item.description: Israel’s strike on Hassan Nasrallah was the culmination of several startling moves that suggest the Israeli prime minister feels unconstrained by foreign criticism.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel spoke on Friday at the meeting of the United Nations General Assembly in New York.

item.title: Why the World’s Biggest Powers Can’t Stop a Middle East War
item.description: The United States’ ability to influence events in the Mideast has waned, and other major nations have essentially been onlookers.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man walking through the rubble of buildings in Baalbek, Lebanon, last week after Israeli airstrikes.

item.title: Can Mainstream Media Save Itself?
item.description: A panel at the Athens Democracy Forum explores how and whether traditional news organizations can regain the influence and trust that once defined them.
item.dc:creator: Farah Nayeri
item.media:credit: Ahmed Gaber for The New York Times
item.media:description: The business of news is under siege, with newspapers facing diminishing readership and revenues. Some 2,900 newspapers in the United States have shuttered since 2005.

item.title: In a Year of Elections, Democracy is on the Line
item.description: Experts at the Democracy Forum in Athens this week will explore the global challenges to democracy and attempt to weigh how endangered it really is.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Silvana Flores/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Mexico’s Supreme Court of Justice of the Nation on Sept. 12. Activity there was suspended pending judicial reforms proposed by the departing president, Andrés Manuel López Obrador.

item.title: Put Vladimir Putin on Trial for War Crimes? That’s One Lawyer’s Demand.
item.description: The human rights barrister Geoffrey Robertson argues that even a trial in absentia would have impact and could vindicate international law.
item.dc:creator: Farah Nayeri
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: The aftermath of a missile strike in Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine, in October 2022. “I don’t think there’s very much that Putin could say,” the lawyer Geoffrey Robertson said of the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin. “We’ve got television pictures of his tanks rolling toward Kyiv. We know exactly what he did, what he ordered.”

item.title: Studying at an English-Speaking University? In Quebec, That May Cost Extra.
item.description: Quebec says a new policy to charge some students higher tuition at top universities in Montreal is needed to preserve the province’s French identity.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai and Nasuna Stuart-Ulin
item.media:credit: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times
item.media:description: McGill University students on the campus grounds in downtown Montreal.

item.title: Iran Projects Caution After Israeli Strikes Against Hezbollah
item.description: Leaders in Tehran suggested it would be the Lebanese militia that would strike back at Israel after the killing of Hassan Nasrallah and bombings in Beirut.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Government supporters in Tehran’s Palestine Square mourning the death of Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of the Lebanese militia Hezbollah, on Saturday.

item.title: As Austrians Vote, Far Right Awaits Its Biggest Success
item.description: The Freedom Party has made itself the country’s most popular party, with calls to bar asylum seekers. It is poised to come out on top in parliamentary elections for the first time.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Christian Bruna/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Herbert Kickl, the leader of the right-wing Austrian Freedom Party, in February.

item.title: Death of Nasrallah, Hezbollah’s Leader, Pushes Mideast Conflict Into New Territory
item.description: His death is a blow to Hezbollah, the militia force and Iranian proxy he led. Whether it will cripple the group, or fuel another cycle of retribution, remains to be seen.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Ronen Bergman, Patrick Kingsley and Steve Lohr
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: The aftermath of an Israeli airstrike on the southern suburbs of Beirut on Friday that killed Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of Hezbollah.

item.title: As Hezbollah Threat Loomed, Israel Built Up Its Spy Agencies
item.description: After the 2006 war with Hezbollah, Israel invested heavily to intercept the group’s communications and track its commanders in a shadowy war that ultimately led to the killing of the group’s leader.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman, Ronen Bergman, Julian E. Barnes and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A billboard featured Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah in the Bekaa Valley of Lebanon.

item.title: Israeli Military Video Shows Nasrallah Likely Killed by 2,000-Pound Bomb
item.description: A Times analysis of video from the Israeli military shows that at least eight planes it said were used in the attack on Hassan Nasrallah were armed with bunker-buster bombs.
item.dc:creator: Aric Toler and Riley Mellen

item.title: Here’s Who Remains in Hezbollah’s Leadership
item.description: Israel has recently killed several commanders of the Lebanese militia, including its longtime leader, Hassan Nasrallah.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Lauren Leatherby
item.media:credit: Aaron Boxerman, Laz Gamio and Lauren Leatherby/The New York Times

item.title: Protesters Mourn Nasrallah’s Death Around the World
item.description: Protesters gathered on Saturday not only in Lebanon, but also in Iran, in the West Bank and elsewhere to mourn his assassination.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourning in Palestine Square in Tehran on Saturday.
